explanation: Agent A’s report is correct in the absence of a safe-iteration guarantee in the for_each_linux_bus macro. MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 requires that the for-loop’s condition and iteration expressions do not depend on objects that may be modified by the loop body (including by functions called from the body). In metal_linux_bus_init the loop macro for_each_linux_bus(lbus) drives the loop control using list/head/next pointers, and the loop body calls metal_linux_probe_bus(lbus). metal_linux_probe_bus may call metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus) which is very likely to remove/modify the same list nodes used by the iterator. If for_each_linux_bus expands to a straightforward list-iteration (using the list links directly) this is a breach of clauses 2/3 of Rule 14.2 because the loop-control objects are modified by the body (via called functions). The only way this would not be a violation is if the macro is explicitly implemented as a “safe” iterator that precomputes the next element (e.g. stores next before invoking the body) or otherwise guarantees the loop-control objects are not modified by the body. No such macro definition was provided, so the agent’s claim that Rule 14.2 is violated is valid unless the for_each_linux_bus macro is a safe-iteration variant. Recommended remediation: use a safe iterator (pre-fetch next) or restructure so the loop control variables cannot be altered by called functions.
